metadata.label: Transcript

M 6 6 43
R 6 10 43
June 5th
Dear Sidney,
It is nine o'clock Saturday evening and I am sitting in Rose's
bed room where the air conditioner works so that I can write to you.
You c an not immagine the heat to-day -it seems almost worse than at any time
last year, maybe because it is the first few weeks of it and I am not yet
accustomed to it. My office was 98 all day and we sat in pools of water.
Landine Melle. and I had supper in the garden but it felt no better than the house.
One of those really miserable evenings. Your lovely flowers have arrived and Ihav
them all in here beside me where it is cool and they will keep. Big enormous floppy  
peonies, pink snapdragons[,] and blue cornflowers. They are so lovely sweet heart
and I love so thinking that they come from you.
The mails once more have momentarily let up,and I have had no word
for a week. Maybe to-morrow the postman will bring me one. I hope so.
Last night Margaret Griggs gave a dinner in her garden for Hampton
Barnes and Evvie was so thrilled and excited it was delightful. We sat in the gardn
till after 1.30 A.M. The latest I have been up in Washington. Harry Ho[p]kins and Loui[s,]
the Duy Gates' Russ Forgan, and loads of others I did not know. We just sat at
our tables and talked till we thoughtmwe had all better go home to our hot houses.
I thought how beautiful it would have been if the party had been in Honolulu, and
we could have looked at the sea, and smelt the flowers, instead of leaning against
the neighbors back fence and sweltering on our party chairs. All these Georgetown
gardens are small but it certainly is better than sitting indoors.
I tried to paly tennis this evening with Reggie Winn in the park at
the top of the hill but all the courts were taken and the players were so selfish
and rude they had no thought of relinquishing their courts,although they had palyed
for an hour[,]so we came home and called it a day.
I am going out to Chevey Chase again to morrow with Landine and hope
to find a game of tennis when I get out there. I dont know any of the playing
members so can not arrange it in advance. However I am sure I can get a game.
I really have no news darling to tell you. The office Job grindes on
and there continues to be talk of people getting overseas, but [I] dont know. I
ceratinly would like to leave the Washington summer beh_ind me and go anywhere.
If only it could be Hawaii. It seems that portion of the country is not going to
open for us for a long time, and I dont know when I can get out there. I might get
to London which would be more interesting than this place anyway[,] andmceratinly not
as hot. However I really put no faith in any of it as nothing yet had materialised
in anything I thought I was going to do,
The strikes continue although it seems the situation is going to
be better as a bill has been passed to make strikes elegal. I dont know why they
did not pass it years ago when all this began. It makes everyone so mad to thinkt
they can get away w[i]th it when everyone else is having a tough time and these people
are living on the fat of everything. Its just a disgrace. "Shocking" as Carole
would say.
[End Page 1]
2
Hampton Barnes tells me that out there in the Pacific you really get very little
news of what goes on anywhere else. Dont you want me to send you the Sunda[y] papers
once a week or is that not possible? The Submarine warfare is really improving.
Subs are really being sunk which is the most encourraging news of all. I think
the European picture will be an impressive one this summer[,]and I certainly hope
we get this inv_asion successfully over with in the not too distant future.
I am really looking forward to my trip the week end of the 12th
when I go to watch Hill with the children to settle them for the summerin their
cottage. The thought of a swim really thrills me. It is so exciting to think of
lying on a beach if for only a day. It will be the most wonderful thing I have done I
since the last time you and I were together there nearly a year ago. That is last
time I have been in the sea. Think of it! Well my darling I hope as time goes byy 
you dont love me any less,or miss me any less,or forget me any more. Its alot to
hope for when we are so far away for so long. Maybe some day we can make up for
all this lost time, these empty days and these dreary nights. I hope so.
I am afraid my letters must be getting so dull to read. I never p
am able to tell you anything pleasant and delightful.Just dinner parties. There
is little else to look forward to frankly other than meeting new f_aces[,]and hearing
new thoughts, and new war angles[,]and news. Its the stimulas after working hours.
Next Wednesday I have Director Hobby, Miss Charlotte, and an
Air Marshal Welsh comming for dinner. I keep inviting my Boss the General but he
seems always too tied up to accept.
Rose has gone to New York to buy groceries for the house at
Watch Hill[,]and get things organized to ship up there. I dont know what I would
do without her. She does everything. A really wonderful person.
The children took a picnicx supper last night and ate it in the
park as it was cooler. I joined them up there for an hour and it was really so ple-
asant after the heat of the office. They thought it hot which amused me. I wish thy
could feel my room where I sit,
Well my sweetheart I have no lovely discriptions to charm you 
with, or amusing anecdotes to tell. Josephine- our Jo is back from London and I
dont believe she covered herself with glory either.
Loads of love to you my darling. I think of you so much[,]and
love you so much.
Honey is here besides me and he looks more like Clippy every day.
Bo loves him and pulls him about and it does not bother him at all. He just thumps
that long tail of his[,]and looks foolish and pleased. He is a sweet doddles and Iam
so glad he is going north with the children. It was one reason for taking the
cottage. He is a lovely animal and I cant tell you what an ache in the heart he giv[e]
me- he is so Clippiish.
I have no Plantation news as Miss Fanucan writes practically not  
at all.
All love sweet ears.Love to Morris too.
Gertie.
I met Alice Longworth the other night and we had a knockdown drag out battle of w
words. What a woman! She attacked Foxcroft[,]and I attcked her[,]and we went to town.
She just tries to be clever and amusing at anyones expense. A real monster I though[t.]
[End Page 2]
